intro: Glyptopetalum ilicifolium, commonly known as the holly-leaved rock heath, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen shrub form. The plant features small, leathery leaves that resemble those of holly, giving it its common name. Its flowers are typically white or pale pink, and it produces berries that are edible but not widely consumed by humans. Glyptopetalum ilicifolium thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or forested habitats.
